credentials: PHD 1987 Univ of IL at Urbana-Champaign
name: TIM OSSWALD

ratings.comment: He's a great guy but a bad professor. Interesting lectures, actually wants to be there. However, this is the worst course structure I've ever experienced. The only assignments are labs and exams, and the labs are so different from lectures they should be a different course. As a result, studying for exams is extremely difficult.

Although he is very interested in what he teaches, he treats students as knowledgeable colleagues, leading to confusing exam questions and completely disorganized lab structure. He also is terrible at operating technology required to lead lectures. I was interested in the first part of the course, but found it less than ideal towards the end.

Professor Osswald really knows his stuff, but the class structure/flow seemed kind of random (especially after spring break). Im not very interested in the material personally, so the lectures were also pretty boring. He cares about his students and doesnt write trick questions in the exams, its mostly the class structure I have a problem with.

He definitely is very knowledgeable on the material for lecture and is very passionate.  A bit hard to pay attention to as he goes off on a LOT of tangents.  Exams were surprisingly difficult in comparison to the labs and lecture material.

This class is definitely worth taking if you are looking to work for any plastics manufacturing company. It is more in depth than ME 313 or ME 418 (also taught by Tim). You should prepare for exams with practice problems from the book. Sometimes you have to use excel for homework problems. Making a study group for the class is helpful!

Not a fan. The homework assignments do almost nothing to help you understand the content of the class. Instead, the homework asked you to make huge graphs using technology that was never discussed in class. Most of the students in the class are graduate students . There is also a prerequisite course that was not listed on the course page. STAY AWAY
I've had Osswald now for 3 classes. He's the Polymer God.
Tim knows polymers like no other. He is a great professor and very genuine. He actually cares about students. All his grad students love him. Take any of his classes and you won't regret it.

Tim is a great professor who wants you to learn. He doesn't have the mindset, you either get this or you don't. He has been around awhile and has many connections around the world. His classes are all lecture heavy but worth it. The HW can be difficult.

Tim is a top polymers professor. He is very easy to talk to and runs a great lab. The lectures can be slightly dry but working in the lab is fun. I want more lab stuff. Great guy and not out to get students like some professors seem they are.
Tim is known around the world. If you are into polymers take all the classes you can with him. He has a great lab that he runs and his knowledge is amazing.

I have to say his lecture is amazing, and you can feel free to talk to him about the class materials. The exam is kind of hard because you will suddenly find the exam is tomorrow and there is just lecture notes and the book that you can review. Generally he is the professor that I will respect.

So no hw in this class. A good thing, right? Not really, as it all comes down to one test that is open book and note. Just so broad it is hard to focus on what to study. Great guy though, very smart and a top polymers professor in the entire world. Leading edge stuff. Great for grad students.
passionate professor, relevant subject matter, educational class. easy to get a good grade as he "doesn't believe in exams" take it.

Osswald is a great guy. He has a good sense of humor and takes an approach to teaching that is very refreshing. He fosters interest of the subject matter in his students through his lectures by bringing his own passion for the subject along with his knowledge and show-and-tell items. Definitely no excuse to not get an A in the class.

Pretty awesome teacher. Very helpful. Let me take the exams with my boss as the proctor while on a deployment.  The first 8 lectures or so were all just the history of polymers. Refers to himself as a "frustrated historian." Very interesting, as good as watching a history channel show to be honest.  Book is a must for tablescharts. Not  on web.
Excellent lecture skills, very enthusiastic about what he does and very easy exam
He is great.  He will keep you interested throughout lecture, and he is an extremely nice, helpful person.  All professors should strive to be like this guy.

Best Prof I've had. I had no interest in polymers before his class, now I'm considering a career in it. The first two weeks are just history based(not tested on) but I'm still taking notes regardless, because he makes it that interesting. Tell me that's not a good professor.
The best teacher I have ever had in my entire undergrad engineering degree. You have to take a class with him before graduating. Best prof. hands down.
Awesome professor. Favorite so far here. Lectures are very interesting, relates them to real world examples, not just academia. Look forward to taking another with him.
Great guy, its videotaped in case you missed something.  Tests are straightforward.  Lots of notes to take but they are useful since you can use them on the exams.
An excellent professor and an excellent class.
Probably the best professor I've ever had. Once you start taking classes from him, you may never want to stop. You may end up wanting to go to graduate school in polymers even.

Very respecting in the field of polymers. Wants his students to be interested in polymers as much as he is. The homeworks and tests are not very hard. Take the online version and watch the lectures at 2x because he talks kind of slow.

Tim is an awesome professor.  He is very interested in the subject matter and passes that along to the students.  The class and labs are fairly easy. He is great help outside class and really nice guy to talk to.  Definitely get to know him outside class!
